For the Italian commune, see [[Leffe, Lombardy]].'' {{ infobox beverage | name = Leffe | image = [[Image:Leffe (Beer).png|center|140px|Logo of Leffe]] | type = [[Beer]] | abv = | proof = | manufacturer = [[InBev|InBev Belgium]] | distributor = [[Anheuser–Busch InBev]] | origin = [[Belgium]] | introduced = | discontinued = | colour = | flavour = | variants = | related = | website =http://www.leffe.com }} '''Leffe''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|l|ɛ|f}} is a premium beer [[brand]] owned by [[InBev|InBev Belgium]], the European operating arm of the global [[Anheuser–Busch InBev]] brewery giant. There are several beers in the range, and they are marketed as [[Abbey beer]]s. They are brewed in large quantities and are widely distributed. ==History== The abbey of Leffe was founded in 1152 on the [[Meuse River]] in the province of [[Namur (province)|Namur]] in southern Belgium. Like many monasteries across Europe, the [[Premonstratensian]] (Norbertine) canons of the abbey brewed ale, starting in 1240.[[www.leffe.com/en/history www.leffe.com/en/history]] Using knowledge passed from generation to generation and ingredients found in the wild near the abbey, the canons developed a unique ale with a subtle taste and high alcohol content, brewed only at the abbey. The abbey has been damaged by both natural and human circumstances over the years: it was destroyed by a flood in 1460, a fire swept through the settlement in 1466, billeted troops damaged the brewery in 1735, and the outbreak of the [[French Revolution]] in 1794 resulted in it being abandoned and the brewery destroyed. The [[Canon (priest)|canons]] returned in 1902. In 1952 the production of beer was continued after a partnership with the [[Flemish Region|Flemish]] based Lootvoet brewery in [[Overijse]]. This brewery was later bought by the international beer company [[Interbrew]] (now [[AB InBev]]). Leffe was then brewed in [[Mont-Saint-Guibert]] until Interbrew closed that brewery. Now all Leffe brands are brewed at the [[Stella Artois]] brewery in [[Leuven]]. The 1952 agreement between the Leffe abbey and a commercial brewery is said to have been the first of its kind (royalties continue to be paid to the abbey). Today, Belgium's beer category called "abbey" is thriving - with several beers brewed under similar licences to Leffe as well as abbey beers named after abbey ruins or abbeys that no longer exist. The [[Heineken brands#Affligem Brewery|Affligem]] and [[Grimbergen (beer)|Grimbergen]] beers are a part of [[Heineken International|Heineken's]] international portfolio. Other notable abbey brands include [[Corsendonk]]. The Leffe museum in the town of [[Dinant]] is open to visitors. ==Brands== [[File:Leffe blonde.jpg|thumb|Leffe blonde]] {| class="wikitable" |- !
